awd_titl_txt: Conference: Special Session on Language Technology at the 2024 Algonquian Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a special session on language technology in conjunction with the 56th Algonquian Conference. The session features speakers on using information technology to advance the study of endangered languages, providing insight into how technology, especially concerning archives, is making the analysis of language faster and more complete, especially for under-resourced languages. The session is important to fostering scientific collaboration between academic linguists and tribes that are in need of understanding the inner workings of their heritage languages. The ability to make better use of archives enhances the ability of Indigenous and non-Indigenous scholars alike to gain more insights about Native American languages and to advance language revitalization.

There were more than 300 languages spoken in North America at the time of European contact. There are perhaps 50 language families that can be recognized for those languages, including the Algonquian family. All the families have different traits, but one consistent feature is the use of complex morphology and a greater importance of verbs than nouns compared to many other languages. These typological characteristics are very different from English and other languages that have been the subject of most work on language technology. Many recent advances in speech technology are therefore ill-equipped to address Native American languages. In addition, the amount of language material available in Native American languages is usually too restricted for the most common language tools. This session addresses these problems by presenting tools and techniques that scientists and community members can use to get access to archival material and to optimize how it is used. Although the Algonquian Conference is naturally centered on languages from that family, the tools and techniques presented at this special session are general to any language. This award is made as part of a funding partnership between the National Science Foundation and the National Endowment for the Humanities for the NSF Dynamic Language Infrastructure – NEH Documenting Endangered Languages Program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 56th iteration of the Algonquian Conference was held at the First Americans Museum in Oklahoma City, 24-27 October, 2024. This series of conferences brings together academic linguists and tribal language activists (with some attendees being both) to discuss issues in the structure and use of Algonquian languages throughout North America. There were 182 attendees, the majority of whom registered for the conference as a whole; 37 registered just for the banquet at which language activists from Oklahoma Algonquian tribes were honored. The presentations and attendance at the conference highlighted the continuing increase in the number and size of language revitalization programs, as well as the relevance of the linguistic insights into the various languages these programs support.

 

In addition to contributed talks, there was a special session funded by this NSF grant on Language Technology. The funds supported the presentations and attendance of these speakers:

Keynote Address: “Technology for Revitalization: New approaches to archives from National Breath of Life.” Daryl Baldwin (Myaamia Center; Miami Tribe of Oklahoma) and Jerome Viles (Myaamia Center; Confederated Tribes of Siletz Indians).

“Community-friendly portals to language data.” Jonathan Amith (Gettysburg College).

“Promoting online learning with 7000 Languages.” Mosiah Bluecloud (U. Arizona; Kickapoo Tribe of Oklahoma).

“Technology for Anishinaabemowin: Language learning and beyond.” Christopher Hammerly (U. British Columbia).

“Prospects and pitfalls in using Artificial Intelligence (AI) for Algonquian revitalization.” Caroline Running Wolf (FLAIR Initiative; Crow Nation) and Michael Running Wolf (FLAIR Initiative; Northern Cheyenne/Lakota/Blackfeet).

“21st Century Tools for Indigenous Languages.” Antti Arppe (U. Alberta).

 

The grant also supported the attendance of 6 students from academic departments. Thanks to this funding, they not only were able to hear the presentations, they also provided logistical support, which helped them understand the inner workings of academic meetings and contributed to a smoothly-run conference. Several of them were also able to chair sessions, introducing the speakers and fielding questions.

 

The technology discussed is applicable to any language, and there are many non-Algonquian languages in Oklahoma. The grant also allowed two members from each of those 26 tribes to attend the special session. Their attendance also allowed them to have curated introductions to the language archives at the Sam Noble Museum at the University of Oklahoma.

 

Feedback from attendees indicated that the conference was a success; in addition to gaining new knowledge about languages people were excited to expand their networks and skills as a result of having this venue to communicate and share, formally and informally.
